sen.j: 硯箱（すずりばこ）は、硯その他を納めておく箱である。
sen.e: Suzuribako means a box that is used for keeping suzuri (ink stone) and other articles.

sen.j: 硯の他に筆、墨、水滴、小刀、尺、暦その他をも納めることがある。
sen.e: A writing brush, ink, water, a short sword, a ruler and a calendar are sometimes kept in it together with suzuri.

sen.j: 種類として、平硯箱、重硯箱、浅硯箱などがある。
sen.e: There are three kinds of suzuribako, namely hira-suzuribako (flat suzuribako), jyu-suzuribako (multitier suzuribako) and asa-suzuribako (shallow suzuribako).

sen.j: また裏梨子地、表蒔絵、螺鈿、描金などが施されることもあり、上手物は美麗をきわめる。
sen.e: Some products are decorated with nashiji (lacquer ware with a lecked effect), makie (Japanese lacquer sprinkled with gold or silver powder), raden (mother-of pearl inlay work) and/or byokin (Chinese name of makie), and first-class products are extremely beautiful.

sen.e: There used to be a practice under which a person showed a certain article to other persons by putting it on suzuribako or its lid.

sen.e: There is a description in "Utsubo monogatari" saying "When Chunagon (vice-councilor of state) requested paper, someone handed a piece of yellowish paper and a piece of white paper by putting them on the lid of suzuribako".
